title: 113_hr1040
content: The "Flat Tax Act" establishes a new part in the Internal Revenue Code called "The Flat Tax," which includes sections on irrevocable election to be subject to flat tax, tax imposed on individuals, tax imposed on business activities, and tax on noncash compensation provided to employees not engaged in business activity. Individuals can elect to be subject to the flat tax instead of the regular tax, with an exception for innocent spouses. A person engaged in business activity can also make this election. A person engaged in business activity may elect to be subject to the alternative minimum tax imposed by the Secretary. No credits are allowed for any taxable year if this election is in effect. "Tax imposed on individuals under SEC. 60A." Tax imposed on individuals under SEC. 60A is a tax equal to 19 percent of taxable income for the first 2 taxable years and 17 percent for subsequent years. Taxable income is defined as the excess of wages received during the taxable year. The standard deduction for individuals under SEC. 60A is the sum of the basic standard deduction and the additional standard deduction. The basic standard deduction is $32,496 for a joint return. The additional standard deduction for individuals includes $20,739 for a head of household, $16,248 for an unmarried individual or married filing separately, and $6,998 for each qualifying child dependent. The term 'retirement distribution' includes distributions from various retirement plans such as 401(a), 403(a), 403(b), 408(a), 408(b), 457, governmental plans, and trusts under section 501(c)(18). The term 'retirement distribution' encompasses plans, contracts, accounts, annuities, or trusts determined by the Secretary. Taxable income of dependent children under 14 is included without tax liability. Dollar amounts in subsection (c) are adjusted for inflation after 2013. The Secretary determines the dollar amount for cost-of-living adjustments based on the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for each calendar year. The CPI is calculated as the average of the CPI at the end of the 12-month period ending on August 31 of the year. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is used to determine cost-of-living adjustments, with the last CPI for all-urban consumers published by the Department of Labor being utilized. Any increase not a multiple of $10 is rounded up to the next highest multiple of $10. Marital status is determined under section 7703 for this purpose. Tax is imposed on business activities under section 60B. Tax is imposed on every person engaged in a business activity who elects to be taxed under this part. The tax rate is 19% for the first 2 taxable years and 17% for subsequent years. The tax must be paid by the person engaged in the business activity, regardless of their entity type. Business taxable income is defined for tax purposes. The term 'business taxable income' is defined as gross active income minus specified deductions. Gross active income includes receipts from sales or exchanges of property or services in the US and exports from the US in connection with a business activity. The fair market value is used for exchanges of property or services. The fair market value of property or services received, plus any money received, is used to determine business taxable income. Exemptions from tax apply to activities of governmental entities and tax-exempt organizations. Deductions specified in this section are applicable. The deductions specified in this subsection include the cost of business inputs, wages paid in cash for services in the US, and retirement contributions for employees. The term 'cost of business inputs' refers to the expenses incurred for the business activity. The term 'cost of business inputs' includes amounts paid for property or services used in connection with a business activity, as well as any taxes imposed on the purchase of property or services for business use, excluding certain specified taxes. The taxable income from financial intermediation services is based on the value of the services provided. Exchanges of property or services are valued at fair market value plus any money paid. The credit-equivalent of excess deductions can be carried over to the following taxable year if deductions exceed gross active income. This does not apply to services performed by an employee for their employer. The excess credit from deductions can be carried over to the following taxable year, with the excess amount multiplied by the 3-month Treasury rate for the last month of the year. This credit can be used against the tax imposed in the next taxable year. The 3-month Treasury rate is determined by the Secretary based on the average market yield on outstanding marketable obligations of the United States with remaining periods to maturity of 3 months or less. Tax on noncash compensation provided to employees not engaged in business activity. Tax is imposed on employers who elect to be taxed under this part, with rates of 19% for the first 2 calendar years and 17% for subsequent years on excludable compensation provided to employees. The employer is liable for paying this tax on any remuneration for services. The term 'excludable compensation' refers to remuneration for services performed as an employee, excluding wages paid in cash, services performed outside the US, and retirement contributions. This section applies to employees of tax-exempt organizations or government agencies. The term 'excludable compensation' refers to remuneration for services performed as an employee, excluding wages paid in cash, services performed outside the US, and retirement contributions. This section applies to employees of tax-exempt organizations or government agencies. Amendment made to the table of parts for subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The Flat Tax amendments apply from 2014. Estate and gift taxes are repealed from 2014 onwards. A supermajority is needed to consider revenue measures. SEC. 4. SUPERMAJORITY REQUIRED TO CONSIDER REVENUE MEASURE. A bill, joint resolution, amendment, or conference report that includes tax rate increases or deduction reductions must be approved by a two-thirds vote in the House of Representatives or the Senate.
